display_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire
headline: Even in the Rising Heat, She Stays Pretty Cool
summary_short: Noomi Rapace brings an intense rightness to the role of Lisbeth Salander in “The Girl Who Played With Fire.”

display_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest
headline: In Trilogy’s Finale, Tough Girl Rages Against Villains of Society
summary_short: “The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet’s Nest” feels like the concluding chapter it is, with neatly tied loose ends and closing remarks, though it unfolds as something of a secular passion play.

headline: Love Amid the Togas and the Intolerant
summary_short: “Agora” is a rousing, toga drama from the Chilean-born director Alejandro Amenábar about the culture wars in ancient Egypt.

headline: Robbed of Youth, and Saddled With Guilt
summary_short: “The Life Before Her Eyes” plays an irritating game of narrative hide-and-seek, continually doubling back on itself to revisit the trauma from which all else evolves.

headline: Big Stars Wielding an Array of Accents, Fighting the War on Terrorism
summary_short: Ridley Scott’s new movie, “Body of Lies,” raises a potentially disturbing question. If terrorism has become boring, does that mean the terrorists have won?

headline: The Virgin Mary as a Teenager With Worries
summary_short: Nothing earth-shaking, but a fine performance by Keisha Castle-Hughes as Mary offers a glimpse of an interesting movie tucked inside what is otherwise an unsurprising and tasteful Christmas pageant.

headline: One Woman's Happiness and Hysteria
summary_short: This rambling high-end soap opera about a woman’s repressed memories of incestuous child was unaccountably nominated for an Oscar for best foreign language film.

headline: Off to Save America With Cape and Mask
summary_short: Like most sequels, this successor to "The Mask of Zorro" feels obliged to outperform its forerunner by being bigger, faster and more spectacular. That translates into busier, sloppier, less coherent and more frantic.

headline: Solving for X: Is She Crazy or a Math Mastermind?
summary_short: A terribly serious adaptation of David Auburn's prize-laden Broadway play starring Gwyneth Paltrow as the daughter of a dead mathematician struggling to come to terms with both her father's legacy and her own troubled mind.

headline: Machines That Rage Against Other Machines
summary_short: This computer-animated film's setting, a world made entirely for and by clanky mechanical gizmos, is rendered with impressive skill and imagination. Otherwise, it's the usual junkyard assemblage of celebrity voices, lame pop-cultural allusions and heartwarming lessons.

headline: A Time of Tangled Transition in Israel, and in a Family
summary_short: The Israeli movie set in 1981 in the early days of the settler movement examines the conflicted desires of a widowed mother who applies for membership in a settlement and her two teenage daughters who are dead set against her joining.

headline: Czechs So Divided That Bad News Is Rarely All Bad
summary_short: This engaging, unruly mix of comedy and melodrama, the Czech Republic’s nominee for the best foreign film Oscar, follows the mood swings suggested by its title. Tracing the generally unhappy doings of a dozen or so loosely connected people in contemporary Prague, it skips from buoyant satire to domestic melodrama, leaving behind a curious mix of emotions.

headline: A Moviemaker Seen Through the Lens of His Son
summary_short: This intimate portrait of the legendary octogenarian cinematographer Haskell Wexler, filmed by his son, is an artistic father-son power struggle for control of a movie being made. It is the richest documentary of its kind since Terry Zwigoff’s "Crumb."

display_title: Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason
headline: Bulking Up for Bridget, Then Diving Into a Pigsty
summary_short: Packing the weight back on, Renée Zellweger again incarnates the plucky heroine of Helen Fielding's chick lit classic, "Bridget Jones's Diary." The new film begins four weeks after the last one left off, with Bridget discovering that her courtly suitor (Colin Firth) has the secret heart of a conservative. Suddenly, womanizing Hugh Grant starts to look a lot better.

headline: A Festival of Cartoons, Not Made for Children
An American in Japan, Making a Connection
summary_short: Sofia Coppola's comic melodrama thoroughly and touchingly bridges the yawning gap between three standards of yearning in movies: David Lean's "Brief Encounter," Richard Linklater's "Before Sunrise" and Wong Kar-wai's "In the Mood for Love."

headline: Everyone's on His Case (Especially His Wife)
summary_short: After grueling workouts in "Training Day" — for which he won his first Best Actor Oscar —  and his directorial debut with "Antwon Fisher," Denzel Washington is on cruise-control for this noir film.

headline: Food for Thought, or Why You Might Skip That Steak
summary_short: Neither high flying enough for the art house nor low down enough for the cult-video shelf, "The Green Butchers," a Danish film about the cannibal business, has pedigree if little else to recommend it.

headline: A Lelouch Jet-Set Fantasy
summary_short: Claude Lelouch ("A Man and a Woman") is the director of this romantic thriller, which was the closing-night feature at the Cannes Film Festival last year.
